prompt: What is the primary objective of High Availability (HA)?
explanation: High Availability ensures continuous access to systems and services for users, minimising service disruption. Module 7: High Availability
options: To ensure continuous access to systems and services
To eliminate the need for routing protocols

prompt: Which statement correctly describes the difference between uptime and availability?
explanation: Uptime does not always equal availability. A system may be running but still not usable, meaning it is not fully available. Module 7: High Availability
options: Availability measures CPU usage while uptime measures memory usage
A system can be running (uptime) but still not usable (availability)
Availability only applies to Layer 2 networks

prompt: What is the main benefit of configuring a LAG?
explanation: LAG combines multiple Ethernet interfaces into one logical link, increasing bandwidth and providing redundancy. Module 7: High Availability
options: Combines multiple interfaces into one logical link for bandwidth and redundancy

prompt: Which feature maintains Layer 3 routing operations during a Routing Engine failover?
explanation: NSR (Nonstop Active Routing) maintains Layer 3 routing operations during Routing Engine failover by synchronising routing information. Module 7: High Availability

prompt: Which features improve uptime and availability in EX Series switches? (Select all that apply.)
explanation: LAG, MC-LAG, GRES, and NSR are all listed as features that improve uptime and availability in EX Series switches. Module 7: High Availability

prompt: Which statements correctly describe MC-LAG? (Select all that apply.)
explanation: MC-LAG extends LAG across multiple switches, provides high availability, and supports link aggregation from WAN to core. Kernel and PFE synchronisation relates to GRES. Module 7: High Availability
options: Extends LAG functionality across multiple switches
Supports link aggregation from WAN to core

prompt: Which statements apply to GRES? (Select all that apply.)
explanation: GRES enables smooth switchover between Routing Engines by synchronising kernel and PFE state, reducing disruption. Module 7: High Availability
options: Enables smooth transition between Routing Engines

prompt: True or False: Higher availability percentages indicate less downtime.
explanation: True. Higher availability percentages (e.g., 99.9%) mean less downtime over time. Module 7: High Availability

prompt: True or False: NSB maintains Layer 2 switching operations during Routing Engine failover.
explanation: True. NSB (Nonstop Bridging) synchronises bridging and switching information to maintain Layer 2 operations during failover. Module 7: High Availability

prompt: Match the HA feature to its function.
explanation: LAG aggregates links, MC-LAG extends aggregation across chassis, NSR maintains Layer 3 routing, and NSB maintains Layer 2 switching during failover. Module 7: High Availability

answers: Combines multiple interfaces into one logical link
Extends link aggregation across multiple switches

prompt: What is the primary purpose of a Link Aggregation Group (LAG)?
explanation: A LAG combines multiple Ethernet interfaces into a single logical link (bundle), increasing bandwidth and redundancy. Module 7: High Availability - LAG
options: To combine multiple Ethernet interfaces into one logical link

prompt: In a LAG configuration where spine1 has two links to leaf1, how are those links presented logically?
explanation: When using LAG, multiple physical links are seen as one logical link or bundle. Module 7: High Availability - LAG
options: As a trunk and an access link

prompt: Which condition must be met for a LAG to form using LACP?
explanation: At least one side must be configured as active for LACP to form the LAG. If both sides are passive, the link will not come up. Module 7: High Availability - LAG
options: At least one side must be active

prompt: What happens if one member link in a LAG fails?
explanation: LAG provides redundancy. If one link fails, traffic continues across the remaining member links. Module 7: High Availability - LAG
options: Traffic continues on the remaining member links

prompt: Which benefits are provided by LAG? (Select all that apply.)
explanation: LAG increases bandwidth, distributes traffic across links, and provides redundancy if a link fails. Module 7: High Availability - LAG

prompt: Which statements are true about LAG member link requirements? (Select all that apply.)
explanation: Member links must match in speed and duplex. Up to 64 links are supported. Contiguous placement is recommended but not required. Module 7: High Availability - LAG
options: All member links must have matching duplex settings
All member links must have matching link speed
Up to 64 member links are supported

prompt: Which statements describe traffic processing in a LAG? (Select all that apply.)
explanation: IP traffic is load-balanced using hashing (default Layer 2), non-IP traffic uses MAC-based hashing, and RE traffic uses the lowest-numbered link. Module 7: High Availability - LAG
options: Non-IP traffic uses source and destination MAC addresses
Routing Engine traffic uses the lowest-numbered member link
All traffic always uses the same single link

prompt: True or False: If both sides of a LAG are configured in passive LACP mode, the LAG will form successfully.
explanation: False. If both sides are passive, LACP PDUs are not initiated and the LAG will not form. Module 7: High Availability - LAG

prompt: True or False: MC-LAG allows a single logical LAG to span across two separate switches.
explanation: True. MC-LAG creates one logical LAG across two separate peer switches using ICCP. Module 7: High Availability - LAG

prompt: Match the LAG-related feature to its description.
explanation: LAG bundles links, MC-LAG spans two switches, ESI-LAG connects clients through combined interfaces in advanced networks, and active LACP mode sends PDUs to establish the link. Module 7: High Availability - LAG

answers: Single logical link from multiple physical links
Logical LAG across two separate switches
Connects client device to peer devices using a combined interface
Sends LACP PDUs to establish aggregation

prompt: On which platforms is GRES typically used?
explanation: GRES is used on switches with dual Routing Engines (REs) or in a Virtual Chassis environment to provide failover capability. Module 7: High Availability - GRESS
options: Switches with dual Routing Engines or Virtual Chassis
Access points with no routing capability

prompt: What happens to the Packet Forwarding Engine (PFE) during a GRES switchover?
explanation: During GRES, the PFE does not restart. It continues forwarding traffic and reconnects to the new primary RE. Module 7: High Availability - GRESS

prompt: What occurs if GRES is enabled but NSR is not?
explanation: GRES does not preserve the control plane. Without NSR enabled, routing protocols (rpd) restart and must relearn routes. Module 7: High Availability - GRESS
options: Routing protocols restart and must relearn routes

prompt: Which command manually triggers a Routing Engine switchover?
explanation: The command 'request chassis routing-engine master switch' manually triggers a Routing Engine switchover. Module 7: High Availability - GRESS

prompt: Which states are replicated between primary and backup RE during GRES synchronisation? (Select all that apply.)
explanation: During GRES, the configuration database, kernel state (via ksyncd), and PFE state are replicated between REs. Module 7: High Availability - GRESS

prompt: Which processes rely on the configuration database? (Select all that apply.)
explanation: The configuration database is used by dcd (interfaces), chassisd (hardware), and rpd (routing protocols). ksyncd replicates kernel state. Module 7: High Availability - GRESS

prompt: Which statements describe GRES switchover operations? (Select all that apply.)
explanation: During GRES, REs exchange keepalives, the backup assumes control if keepalives stop, and the PFE reconnects without restarting. Module 7: High Availability - GRESS
options: Primary and backup RE exchange keepalive messages
Backup RE becomes primary if keepalives stop
PFE disconnects from old primary and reconnects to new primary
The PFE always restarts during failover

prompt: True or False: GRES preserves the control plane state by default.
explanation: False. GRES does not preserve the control plane. Routing protocols restart unless NSR is enabled. Module 7: High Availability - GRESS

prompt: True or False: The command 'show system switchover' is used to monitor GRES status.
explanation: True. The 'show system switchover' command is used to monitor GRES status. Module 7: High Availability - GRESS

prompt: Match the GRES component or function to its description.
explanation: GRES provides RE failover with minimal disruption, NSR preserves routing protocol state, ksyncd replicates kernel state, and the PFE continues forwarding during switchover. Module 7: High Availability - GRESS

prompt: What is EVPN multihoming?
explanation: EVPN multihoming connects a customer edge (CE) device to more than one provider edge (PE) router to provide redundancy. Module 7: High Availability - System-ID and Multihoming
options: Connecting a CE device to multiple VLANs on one switch
Connecting a CE device to more than one PE router for redundancy
Running multiple routing protocols on a single PE
Connecting two PEs together without a CE

prompt: How is EVPN information shared between Provider Edge (PE) routers?
explanation: EVPN information is shared between PEs using BGP in an MPLS network environment. Module 7: High Availability - System-ID and Multihoming

prompt: Which EVPN multihoming mode allows all connected PEs to forward traffic simultaneously?
explanation: Active/Active mode allows all connected PEs to forward traffic at the same time, providing better performance and redundancy. Module 7: High Availability - System-ID and Multihoming

prompt: Which EVPN multihoming mode requires ESI configuration?
explanation: Active/Standby (Single-Active) mode requires ESI configuration to manage redundancy between multiple PEs. Module 7: High Availability - System-ID and Multihoming

prompt: Why is EVPN multihoming used? (Select all that apply.)
explanation: EVPN multihoming provides redundancy, keeps traffic flowing if one PE fails, and in Active/Active mode includes built-in loop prevention. It does not eliminate BGP. Module 7: High Availability - System-ID and Multihoming
options: Maintains traffic flow if one PE fails

prompt: Which connectivity options are supported for a CE device in EVPN multihoming? (Select all that apply.)
explanation: A CE device can connect to multiple PEs or use multiple links to one PE. Module 7: High Availability - System-ID and Multihoming
options: Use multiple links to one PE
Connect only through a single VLAN

prompt: Which statements describe Active/Standby (Single-Active) mode? (Select all that apply.)
explanation: In Active/Standby mode, one PE forwards traffic while the other waits as backup and takes over if the active PE fails. Module 7: High Availability - System-ID and Multihoming
options: Backup takes over if the active PE fails

prompt: True or False: Single-Homed mode provides redundancy because the CE connects to multiple PEs.
explanation: False. In Single-Homed mode, the CE connects to only one PE and has no redundancy. Module 7: High Availability - System-ID and Multihoming

prompt: True or False: Active/Active is the default EVPN multihoming mode in Juniper.
explanation: True. Active/Active is the default EVPN multihoming mode in Juniper and allows all PEs to forward traffic simultaneously. Module 7: High Availability - System-ID and Multihoming

prompt: Match the EVPN multihoming mode to its characteristics.
explanation: Single-Homed has no redundancy, Active/Standby uses one active and one backup PE, Active/Active forwards on all PEs, and ESI is required in Single-Active mode. Module 7: High Availability - System-ID and Multihoming
